Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Generation of Sediment Heterogeneity by Macrophytes and Macrofauna and Consequences for Redox Chemistry and Trace Metal Speciation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Intellectual Merit: Coastal and inland wetland areas are enormously impacted by rapidly growing human populations. This typically leads to increased metal and nutrient loading together with significant changes in wetland hydrology, fauna and flora. Sustainable coastal and inland wetland development (and remediation) strategies depend on the development of accurate, predictive models of metal and nutrient speciation, bioavailability and mobility and their dependence on wetland flora and fauna populations. This is particularly true at the sensitive interface between saltmarshes and the coastal ocean or between inland wetlands and freshwater aquifers. Macrophytes and macrofauna inhabiting organic-rich saltmarsh and freshwater wetlands produce significant three-dimensional, temporally varying, geochemical heterogeneity in the surrounding sediments. This has a tremendous influence on benthic fluxes of oxygen, metals and nutrients, internal cycling of redox sensitive chemical species, and organic matter degradation kinetics. The following laboratory and field investigations will be used to assess these influences and to advance the development of sophisticated 3D mathematical models of sediment redox chemistry and trace metal speciation, bioavailability and mobility. (1) Metal adsorption experiments on mixed model mineral assemblages will be used to derive thermodynamic surface complexation stability constants and to assess their applicability to natural sediments. (2) Bulk sediment properties (mineralogy, pore water chemistry, trace metal speciation) in adjacent vegetated and
unvegetated sediments will be measured as part of an innovative new field course at WMU. (3)
Microscale analyses of mineralogy and trace metal speciation in sediments surrounding roots and burrows will be completed using microelectrodes, SEM/TEM, and laser ablation ICP-MS. (4) Changes in trace metal speciation resulting from chemically versus microbially mediated reductive dissolution of trace-metal doped iron oxides will be quantified. (5) Controlled laboratory mesocosm experiments with artificial roots will be used to assess microscale 3D changes in mineralogy and trace metal speciation resulting from root leakage of oxygen and labile organic compounds.

Broader Impacts: This study includes a fully integrated plan of research and education. An innovative 6-week summer course is proposed in which students will have the opportunity to participate in field research at Sapelo Island, Georgia (an NSF-LTER site) and at field sites in Michigan. Students will be recruited for this course from WMU and surrounding institutions, especially those without graduate research programs and from colleges with significant enrollments of traditionally underrepresented groups. In addition, a full week of the course will coincide with a secondary education teacher workshop. The teachers will have a hands-on opportunity to participate in an active scientific research program and will be encouraged to disseminate curricula resulting from this experience at the Michigan Science Teachers Annual
Meeting. Projects related to the laboratory portions of the study will be incorporated into an undergraduate geochemistry course. In addition to traditional graduate student mentoring, undergraduate students and highly motivated high school students from the Kalamazoo Area
Math and Science Academy will participate in all aspects of the research, presenting results of individual projects at national or international scientific conferences. Equipment funded though this study will be a valuable addition to the research infrastructure available to graduate and undergraduate students at WMU, a rapidly growing doctoral research institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trace metal mobility and bioavailability in the environment are largely determined by metal speciation, that is, the chemical form of the metals. Development of better quantitative models to predict metal speciation under a broad range of environmentally-relevant conditions is crucial for remediating contaminated sites and developing a more thorough understanding of the chemistry of natural systems. Current models describing metal partitioning between aqueous solutions and solid surfaces are limited by a paucity of data regarding common environmental substrates and a lack of information regarding interactions among solid surfaces. This study aimed to fill gaps in the scientific knowledge base by investigating reactions between environmentally relevant metals (U, Cr, Cu, Pb, Co, Ni, Cd) and solids (ferrihydrite, kaolinite, quartz, montmorillonite, alumina, manganese oxide, feldspars, aquifer sediments). Binding of the metals to the solid surfaces was measured under a wide range of solution conditions (varying pH, ionic strength, pCO2, sorbate/sorbent ratio), in the presence of competing metals and organic compounds, and for different substrates, including pure minerals, mixtures of pure minerals and natural sediments and soils. The data were used to derive quantitative models that can be used to predict metal speciation under a wide range of environmental conditions.

Through a combination of field and laboratory studies, it was demonstrated that macrophytes (aquatic plants) and macrofauna significantly influence sediment geochemistry, including trace metal speciation, in both saltmarsh  and freshwater wetland sediments via biological activities including exudation of oxygen and organic matter through roots and construction and flushing of burrow habitats. The specific effects are strongly dependent on season, and invasive species, such as purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria), appear to have a particularly large influence on sediment biogeochemistry and trace metal speciation, with important implications for marsh management strategies. The influence of macrofauna on trace metal speciation at burrow walls was also investigated near modern fiddler crab and Pleistocene shrimp burrows collected from sites on Sapelo Island; the data show that metal speciation varies with distance from the burrow wall in these organic-rich, saturated wetland sediments.

This project included a substantial outreach, education and training effort. Thirty-two students (4 doctoral, 8 masters, 14 undergraduate, 7 high school students) and a postdoctoral scholar were trained in analytical, field and/or computational techniques in aqueous geochemistry and completed substantive research as a part of this project. Most of these students are now pursuing higher degrees or are employed by federal or local government agencies, environmental consulting firms, or K12 schools. The work completed by these students and the PI has been broadly disseminated through conference presentations (51 total, including 14 first authored by undergraduates and 25 first authored by graduate students), peer-reviewed journal publications (12 published, 4 in review, 3 in preparation) and more than 15 presentations to the general public. As a part of this project, the PI developed and taught a series of summer courses. The first of these was a 6-week field course in “Biogeochemistry of Wetlands” (summer 2006). Students learned a variety of field and analytical skills during this intensive, 40 hour per week, six week course. The PI also taught two summer workshops for K12 teachers, titled “Wetlands Biogeochemistry” and “Environmental Science” (summer 2006, 2007). Both 40-hr week long courses proved very popular and were oversubscribed.
